webTitle: Sir Thomas Risk obituary

fields.standfirst: Lawyer and governor of the Bank of Scotland who became embroiled in the Guinness affair
fields.body:
Sir Thomas Risk, who has died aged 89, was a third- generation Glasgow lawyer and, from 1981 until 1991, was one of the most successful governors of the Bank of Scotland. However, his name might have remained largely unknown outside Scotland had it not been for his central role in what became known in the 1980s as the "Risk affair", which was itself part of the notorious Guinness affair, that led to many lost reputations, a Department of Trade and Industry inquiry and even prison sentences.

Risk was one of five children of Ralph Risk, one-time president of the Law Society of Scotland. He was sent to the exclusive Kelvinside Academy in Glasgow, and then to Glasgow University, where he read law. From there it was just a short step into the Glasgow law firm of Maclay Murray & Spens, where his father was senior partner.

His legal career was interrupted by the second world war during which he joined the RAF, qualified as a pilot and flew Catalina and Sunderland flying boats. Shortly after the war, while he was still in the RAF, he met in Colombo, Sri Lanka (then Ceylon), his future wife, Suzanne (nee Eiloart), a London girl who, later in life, was dubbed the Bank of Scotland's "first lady". They married in 1949.

After demobilisation, Risk returned to the family firm and quickly earned the trust of the Scottish financial institutions, joining Standard Life Assurance as a non-executive director in 1965, moving to chairman in 1969. In 1977 he became deputy governor of the Bank of Scotland, also taking on the role of governor of its subsidiary British Linen Bank. He was a non-executive director of Merchants Trust and Howden Group. In later years, Barclays Bank and Shell UK also benefited from his boardroom presence.

In May 1981, his grooming for the top job at the Bank of Scotland paid off and he began his decade as governor, overseeing among other things the launch of the UK's first electronic home banking system. Buoyed by North Sea oil, Scotland's finance industry was enjoying rapid growth and Bank of Scotland was in the vanguard. In 1984, Risk was knighted.

Meanwhile, Argyll Group, which had established links with the Edinburgh financial establishment, had spent most of 1985 planning a takeover of Distillers Company, the world's largest producer of Scotch whisky, but was trounced when in January 1986, the stout maker Guinness announced it had itself agreed terms for a "merger" with Distillers.

Argyll weighed in with a counter-offer, and the battle for control of Distillers raged through the early months of 1986, amid accusations of dirty tricks and bending of City takeover rules. Guinness eventually secured Distillers' agreement to a much revised deal, part of which was that a new board would be set up to control the merged entity. The company was to be based in Edinburgh. Furthermore, Ernest Saunders, Guinness chairman and chief executive, boasted that he had persuaded Risk, against his initial misgivings, to be its first chairman.

But once Saunders gained control, Risk was virtually ignored by him and the small coterie of Guinness executives at the helm of the company. Finally, a frustrated Risk insisted on a meeting, during which Saunders told him he had changed his mind and decided that he would be the chairman himself, claiming he needed full executive control of the merged business.

There followed a series of clumsy media attempts to portray Risk as a potential obstacle to progress who wanted executive control, and as a "little Scotlander" who wanted to put his parochial interests above those of the wider group. A rumour was even started that Risk had demanded a larger share of the group's banking business for Bank of Scotland, a claim easily denied by Risk.

The City took a dim view of the affair on the grounds that Distillers shareholders had been influenced by a promise made during the takeover bid which was simply broken once control had been secured. Nevertheless, while it was a precedent which, all seemed agreed, should not be followed, Saunders got his way.

Throughout the furore, Risk remained a respected governor of the Bank of Scotland, during a period when the bank's profits increased for seven years in succession. He had intended to retire in 1988, when he reached 65, but was persuaded to stay on for a further three years.

Encouraged by his wife, he put his influence behind the Edinburgh festival, helping its fundraisers by brokering introductions to potential sponsors. The bank itself sponsored the festival's annual fireworks concert for 16 years until last year.

Risk and his wife were keen travellers, but during his business career he could often frustrate his colleagues by changing his travel plans at short notice in order to fit in "one more meeting". In his younger days he was a keen sprinter, and he played golf and the occasional game of tennis doubles well into his retirement years.

Suzanne died in 2011; Risk is survived by three sons, Keith, Timothy and Colin; a fourth son, Michael, predeceased him.

• Thomas Neilson Risk, lawyer and banker, born 13 September 1922; died 27 June 2012

webTitle: Barclays scandal: exchanges with the Bank of England

fields.standfirst: Some excerpts from documents released by Barclays explaining exchanges it had with the Bank of England
fields.body:
29 October 2008 Communication from Bank of England

During October 2008, in the wake of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, when liquidity conditions had tightened acutely, Barclays raised its US Dollar LIBOR submissions more significantly than other panel members. In the month of October 2008, in particular, Barclays US Dollar LIBOR submissions for the 3 month maturity were the highest or next highest of the panel on every single day of the month and therefore excluded from the calculation of LIBOR. Barclays did not understand why other banks were consistently posting lower submissions; Barclays firmly believed that the other panel members were not, in fact, funding at a lower cost than Barclays, and we were disappointed that no effective action was taken, notwithstanding our having raised these issues with various Authorities during the whole financial crisis period as outlined in the attached timeline.

As one would expect, Barclays (including Bob Diamond and Jerry del Missier) was in close contact with the Bank of England and other Authorities about the liquidity crisis generally. On 29 October 2008, Bob Diamond received a call from Paul Tucker, the Deputy Governor of the Bank of England. The substance of that call was captured by Bob Diamond via a note prepared at the time. A copy of that note is appended to this document; it was circulated to John Varley, then Barclays Chief Executive, and Jerry del Missier, then President of Barclays Capital.

Subsequent to the call, Bob Diamond relayed the contents of the conversation to Jerry del Missier. Bob Diamond did not believe he received an instruction from Paul Tucker or that he gave an instruction to Jerry del Missier. However Jerry del Missier concluded that an instruction had been passed down from the Bank of England not to keep LIBORs so high and he therefore passed down a direction to that effect to the submitters.

Supplementary information regarding Barclays settlement with the Authorities in respect of their investigations into the submission of various interbank offered rates

From: Diamond, Bob: Barclays Capital

Sent: 10/30/2008 14:19:54

To: Varley, John: Barclays PLC

Cc: del Missier, Jerry: Barclays Capital (NYK)

Subject: File note: Bank of England call

Fyi

File Note: Call to RED [Diamond] from Paul Tucker, Bank of England

Date: 29th October 2008

Further to our last call, Mr Tucker reiterated that he had received calls from a number of senior figures within Whitehall to question why Barclays was always toward the top end of the Libor pricing. His response was "you have to pay what you have to pay". I asked if he could relay the reality, that not all banks were providing quotes at the levels that represented real transactions, his response "oh, that would be worse".

I explained again our market rate driven policy and that it had recently meant that we appeared in the top quartile and on occasion the top decile of the pricing. Equally I noted that we continued to see others in the market posting rates at levels that were not representative of where they would actually undertake business. This latter point has on occasion pushed us higher than would otherwise appear to be the case. In fact, we are not having to "pay up" for money at all.

Mr Tucker stated the levels of calls he was receiving from Whitehall were 'senior' and that while he was certain we did not need advice, that it did not always need to be the case that we appeared as high as we have recently.

RED [Diamond]

webTitle: Harrods owner plans luxury hotel chain

fields.bodyText: The Qatari owner of Harrods plans to take the department store brand global by building upmarket hotels bearing its name in cities around the world, including one Chelsea Barracks in London. Qatar Holding, part of the emirate's sovereign wealth fund, announced it was diversifying into hospitality as part of a grand plan to make Harrods a global luxury brand. "The target plan is to open Harrods hotels in key cities such as Kuala Lumpur, New York and Paris as well as in China," a spokesman said. "Preference will be given to construct on sites already owned by Qatar Holding or its affiliates, for example at Chelsea Barracks in London or Costa Smeralda in Sardinia. Qatar Holding ultimately intends to grow Harrods into a global enterprise that defines the luxury retail and leisure sectors." The Doha-based fund bought Harrods from Mohamed Al Fayed for £1.5bn in 2010 and is fast becoming a kingmaker in British property development, snapping up a series of trophy sites in the past five years including Chelsea Barracks, the luxury apartment complex at One Hyde Park, the US embassy in Grosvenor Square and the Olympic Village, which it will take over after the Games. On Thursday the Qatari premier, Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber al-Thani, will arrive in the UK to open the latest property on his London Monopoly board: the 72-storey Shard, which is 95%-owned by Qatar. The Qatar Holding vice-chairman, Hussain Ali Al Abdulla, in Malaysia to unveil plans for the first hotel, reportedly told journalists: "We have already decided to build a Harrods hotel in London, one in Kuala Lumpur and one in Sardinia." Qatari Diar, the sovereign wealth developer, bought Chelsea Barracks from the Ministry of Defence for nearly £1bn in 2007 and its outline masterplan for a £3bn redevelopment was approved last year. The site has remained undeveloped since the last troops vacated the premises in 2008. Qatar also owns 26% of J Sainsbury, 28% of Canary Wharf's owner, Song Bird Estates, and sizeable chunks of Barclays and the London Stock Exchange It's not all about luxury, however. The Qatar Investment Authority also owns 20% of Camden market in north London, via its holding in the property group Chelsfield.

webTitle: IMF admits US recovery is 'tepid' but urges Obama to avoid drastic cuts

fields.standfirst: Christine Lagarde delivers gloomy forecast for president, but says attempts to cut spending too quickly would be 'excessive'
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund has advised the Obama administration not to tighten its belt too quickly to reduce the public deficit, warning that to do so could further weaken the US economy by the end of this year with possible global implications.

In its report for 2012, the IMF has delivered a pessimistic forecast for the US economy, predicting that growth will remain modest over the next two years. The fund's managing director, Christine Lagarde, said that America's economic recovery "remains tepid. It is economic recovery, we are in positive territory, but it is tepid".

She pointed to two main risks facing the world's largest economy: exposure to the potential contagion spreading out from the euro debt crisis, and political uncertainty in Washington that was preventing agreement on fiscal policy that in turn threatened to push the US off a "fiscal cliff".

The relatively gloomy prediction from the IMF that growth will be limited to 2% for the rest of this year, rising barely to 2.25% in 2013, will come as bleak news for Barack Obama as he enters the final straight of a presidential election overwhelmingly geared to the state of the American economy.

The IMF's forecast is likely to be seized upon by Mitt Romney, who has made what he calls the "Obama promise gap" on creating new jobs a keystone of his campaign.

But the statement also carries dangers for Romney, as the IMF comes down clearly on the side of stimulating the recovery and against any premature attempt to cut public spending. webTitle: Banking scandal: Tory inquiry plans mired in dispute

fields.standfirst: George Osborne's response to the Libor scandal has been challenged by both the Treasury select committee and Labour
fields.body:
Government efforts to set up a parliamentary inquiry into the banking crisis are in disarray, after Treasury select committee members insisted that they should conduct the inquiry, and Labour accused the chancellor of attempting to rig the process to heap the blame on the previous government.

The Treasury select committee, which is on Wednesday due to cross-examine the former chief executive of Barclays, Bob Diamond, met in private on Tuesday to hear cross-party demands that it conduct the inquiry. Members pointed out the committee had the requisite expertise and experience of cross-party co-operation to conduct an effective inquiry.

Andrew Tyrie, the chairman of the committee, who was chosen by the government to chair the joint parliamentary inquiry, was requested by his fellow committee members to go back to the chancellor to hold further discussions. One committee source said: "Tyrie was not given a mandate to go ahead and chair the joint parliamentary inquiry. If there is to be parliamentary inquiry, we should do it."

The government confirmed that there will be a commons debate on Thursday about the inquiry, in a bid to impose some order. The political wrangling over how the inquiry into banking should be conducted came hours after Bob Diamond announced he was stepping down as Barclays chief executive in the wake of the bank's £290m fine for interest rate rigging.

An attempt by the board to save Diamond's job by accepting the resignation, 24 hours earlier, of chairman Marcus Agius had backfired. Agius will now become full-time chairman and lead the search for a new chief executive.

Diamond, who has earned £100m since he joined the bank's board six years ago, decided on Monday night he could no longer tough it out after attending a rehearsal for his appearance on Wednesday in front of the Treasury select committee.

It is understood that, in telephone calls on Monday evening, Bank of England governor Sir Mervyn King and chairman of the Financial Services Authority (FSA) Lord Turner also exerted pressure on the Barclays board.

Diamond's decision to go was relayed to the Barclays directors in a hastily convened late-night telephone board meeting, and announced at 7.30am.

Speaking at an FSA public meeting on Tuesday morning, Turner said: "There were major challenges for Barclays in making sure they could convince people there had been fundamental cultural change and we simply communicated to the board that these were the issues they needed to think about; it was for them to agree whether they could achieve that degree of change under the current leadership."

Diamond's departure was followed this afternoon by that of Jerry del Missier, the chief executive's long-time lieutenant, who was promoted to chief operating officer last month. Barclays said del Missier had been cleared by the FSA of any wrongdoing.

Labour is calling for a full judge-led inquiry into the banking crisis, instead of the joint parliamentary inquiry being instigated by George Osborne. Tyrie has said he will only chair it with cross-party support, in effect giving Labour a veto over the process.

Peers are due to vote on whether to set up a judicial inquiry on Tuesday. Miliband said: "If he doesn't order that judge-led inquiry, I think he will be failing to understand both the gravity and scale of this crisis. We've had missed opportunities before; we've got to seize this moment."

It is understood that Labour and Tory MPs are concerned by the way Osborne has sought to limit the scope and the membership of the proposed inquiry. Labour MPs also believe Osborne sees the inquiry solely as an attempt to put Ed Balls, the shadow chancellor, in the dock for failing to regulate the banks properly in the middle of the last decade.

They point out that no party's hands are clean, and highlight the fact that Lord Green, the trade minister and former chairman of HSBC, was chairman of the British Banking Association at the time of the Libor crisis.

At a series of private meetings, MPs on the committee have questioned the chancellor's proposal to limit the terms of the inquiry to the Libor issue. There are also concerns that the inquiry will have only nine members – five MPs and four peers.

There are suspicions about Osborne's intentions because the main peer on the committee would be Lord MacGregor of Pulham Market, a loyalist who is vice-chairman of the association of Conservative peers.

The battle over the inquiry is turning into a political trial of strength with David Cameron determined to be seen in charge of events.

In an interview on Monday night, Tyrie said he would not go ahead with the joint parliamentary committee inquiry until there is a clear Labour support in a motion passed by both Houses – effectively giving Miliband a veto over the plans.

The cabinet discussed the issue briefly this morning, and said it would be tabling a motion in the Commons and Lords shortly.

In a sign of fresh flexibility over the terms of reference of the joint inquiry, the prime minister's spokesman said: "A parliamentary inquiry can make judgments about precisely what issues they look at." However, he insisted it was important for the inquiry to be completed quickly so any recommendation could be absorbed into imminent legislation on financial regulation and banking.

Labour has claimed the terms of reference proposed by the government on Monday were too narrow. The party said the inquiry was being asked "to look at the Libor rate-setting process and what lessons could be learnt from them in relation to transparency, conflicts of interest culture and the professional standards of the banking industry".

Labour said these terms of reference restrict an inquiry into Libor and not wider issues of banking over the past decade. The government disagrees, saying the inquiry is broader.

The Liberal Democrats have supported a parliamentary inquiry, as opposed to one led by judges. Stephen Williams, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, said it would reflect badly on parliament if it felt it could not conduct an inquiry into an issue like this.

webTitle: Banks now have more liquid assets but solvency threat remains

fields.standfirst: A fresh setback for the world economy would mean a sharp increase in bad debts and lower profits for banks, but they are continuing to stockpile high-quality liquid assets
fields.body:
To put it mildly, this is not the best of times for the UK banking industry. The scandal at Barclays that has claimed the scalp of Bob Diamond follows the IT screw-up at the Royal Bank of Scotland, and comes at a time when the crisis in the eurozone has led to fears of a global double-dip recession. Funding costs for banks have already been rising but a fresh setback for the world economy would mean a sharp increase in bad debts and lower profits.

As the Bank of England noted last week, banks have been building up capital to protect themselves against another downturn, but not quickly enough to cope with the sort of storm that would be the consequence of a break-up (or even a threatened break-up) of the eurozone.

The one piece of good news, reflected in the monthly banking statistics released by Threadneedle Street on Tuesday, is that banks are continuing to stockpile high-quality liquid assets. These are assets – such as government gilts, US Treasury bills and reserves held at the Bank of England – that can be turned into cash at very short notice if need be.

Back in the 1960s, UK banks held around 25% of their assets in this form, but the so-called liquidity ratio declined decade after decade as banks lent more and accumulated lower-grade and less liquid assets.

According to Michael Saunders, UK economist at Citigroup, high-quality liquid assets of UK banks were just £10bn – 0.3% of the total – on the eve of the financial crisis in 2007. The latest data for May 2012 show that high quality liquid assets now stand at £356bn – almost 10% of the total and the highest percentage for at least 30 years.

The improved liquidity position will not help all that much in the event of widespread losses caused by Great Recession Part Two. That would be a solvency rather than a liquidity crisis.

Even if the worst-case scenario is avoided, with the eurozone getting on top of its problems and the global economy gradually picking up steam in 2013, it is clear the improved financial position for the banks has not made them any keener to lend, particularly to small businesses. Saunders points out that the average lending rate for loans of under £1m – the sort of loan likely to be granted to a small or medium-sized company – increased from 3.71% to 3.83% May. That compares with the Bank of England's key bank rate of 0.5%.

Although lending rates for loans in excess of £20m fell slightly, it is the SME sector that tends to rely most heavily on bank finance and there is little sign that things are getting better. Hence the various plans for credit easing, funding for lending and for more quantitative easing, all of which are designed to increase the flow of lending from the banks to the private sector.

webTitle: Bob Diamond resigns from Barclays – but who should replace him?

fields.bodyText: Bob Diamond's departure from the chief executive's chair at Barclays leaves a vacancy that many analysts believe will be hard to fill. Without any obvious succession planning, the bank's board is being forced to cast its net wide and consider candidates from all corners of the industry. That said, there are several candidates who have emerged on the leaderboard. Bill Winters, a former investment banker at the second-largest bank in the US, JP Morgan Chase, is the most talked about candidate. He is cut from the same cloth as Diamond and would give shareholders the same sense of comfort that Barclays will make lots of money from its investment arm, Barclays Capital. Next in line are a group of insiders who, while not natural successors, know the bank and have a powerbase from which to launch their bid. Antony Jenkins, the head of retail and business banking, joined in 2009 and is credited with reducing customer complaints. Naguib Kheraj, the bank's vice-chairman, is a high-profile finance whiz who quit as finance director in early 2007, only to be lured back to take charge of an ultimately failed bid for Dutch bank ABN Amro and then again last year from Lazards into a strategic planning role. Christopher Lucas, a chartered accountant, is finance director. He joined in 2007, but was familiar with the organisation after five years as PricewaterhouseCoopers main link with the bank. David Roberts is another strong contender. Roberts, 50, lost out to Bob Diamond in the race to be chief executive after John Varley's early retirement. He quit the Barclays board in 2006 after more than 20 years service to run an Austrian bank before moving to Lloyds Banking Group to be chairman Win Bischoff's deputy. Last year, he was lined up to take over from Lloyds chief executive António Horta-Osório should he fail to return after a period of ill-health. The blot on his copy book goes back to his time as head of personal financial services during a period when the sales of payment protection insurance accounted for more than 10% of the group's global profits. It's likely the apparent success of the division helped propel him onto the board, but the subsequent mis-selling scandal has cost the bank hundreds of millions of pounds in compensation. Hector Sants, the former boss of the City's main regulator, does not have a job to go to, though he is being forced to take six months' gardening leave, which will keep him out of circulation until Christmas. Sants was an investment banker and head of wholesale markets at the Financial Services Authority in the runup to the financial crisis, before taking on the chief executive role only months before the Northern Rock disaster. He would allow Barclays to present a squeaky clean image after his efforts to clean up the industry, but the board needs someone now, making him a long shot. Benny Higgins, the chief executive of Tesco's Edinburgh-based bank, is another name in the frame. The qualified actuary was credited with running a conservative mortgage loan operation during a stint at Halifax between 2006/07, though he was unable to offset the excesses of the Bank of Scotland division that eventually forced Halifax first into the arms of Lloyds and then the taxpayer. The Barclays board may baulk at the tangled love life of the 51-year-old, who is four times married and spent time in court last year battling over the maintenance of his then 11-year-old daughter by his third wife. Gary Hoffman, who came to prominence as boss of the nationalised Northern Rock, was on the Barclays board at the time of the credit crunch. Hoffman left Northern Rock to make his fortune as a private-equity boss. He attempted to build a banking empire that included buying Northern Rock from the government. But Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group beat him to it and he has since dropped his plans. Ladbrokes have put odds of 100-1 on Gordon Brown taking the helm, though it could add Tony Blair and Sir John Major to the list if there is any inclination to employ an out-of-work senior politician.

webTitle: Ed Miliband: Bob Diamond resignation proves need for judicial inquiry

fields.standfirst: Labour increases pressure for judge-led inquiry into banking as politicians unite in welcoming Barclays chief's decision
fields.body:
Labour has increased the pressure for a judge-led inquiry into the banking industry as politicians unite in welcoming Bob Diamond's decision to stand down as chief executive of Barclays amid the rate-rigging scandal.

Nick Clegg, the Liberal Democrat deputy prime minister, said of Diamond's move: "This was the right decision on his part. People will now want us to get on with the inquiry and take further action fast to ensure that people and businesses are protected."

George Osborne was the first senior government figure to welcome Diamond's resignation, saying he hoped it was "the first step towards a new culture of responsibility in British banking".

The chancellor said he learned on Monday night from the now reinstated Barclays chairman, Marcus Agius, that Diamond would announce his resignation on Tuesday morning. He said it was the "right decision" for the bank and the country but insisted that neither he nor fellow ministers had put pressure on Diamond to resign – that was a decision for the Barclays board, not the government.

Osborne told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme: "I think it's the right decision for Barclays, I think it's the right decision for the country, because we need Barclays bank focused on lending to our economy and not distracted by this argument about who should be in charge."

Diamond, who on Monday issued a memo to staff in which he made clear he had no intention of leaving, finally bowed to pressure to go.

He said in a resignation statement: "The external pressure placed on Barclays has reached a level that risks damaging the franchise … I am deeply disappointed that the impression created by the events announced last week about what Barclays and its people stand for could not be further from the truth."

The move came after Barclays was fined £290m by UK and US regulators for manipulating the Libor and Euribor, the rates at which banks lend to each other.

Agius, who resigned over the affair on Monday, will remain with the bank to lead the search for a new chief executive before stepping down at a later date.

Miliband said of Diamond's resignation: "This was necessary and right. It was clear Bob Diamond was not the man to lead the change that Barclays needed. But this is about more than one man – this is about the culture and practices of the entire banking system, which is why we need an independent, open, judge-led public inquiry."

Accusing David Cameron of "failing to understand the gravity and scale" of the culture banking crisis in Britain's banks, the Labour leader insisted a judicial inquiry was necessary for public confidence.

He said: "The last thing the public want is a sense that the establishment is trying to cover this up, trying to sweep it under the carpet."

He dismissed the notion that a judge-led inquiry would necessarily be more time-consuming than a parliamentary investigation, as proposed by Cameron, saying it could be a "short, quick, forensic inquiry".

webTitle: Recession fears raised as UK construction sector contracts

fields.standfirst: Monthly survey reveals a marked deterioration in business conditions
fields.body:
Fears that Britain's double-dip recession deepened in the second quarter of 2012 heightened on Tuesday after the latest snapshot of the construction sector revealed a marked deterioration in business conditions.

The monthly survey from CIPS/Markit showed that the closely watched Purchasing Managers' Index dropped from 54.4 to 48.2 in June – below the 50 level that separates a sector that is expanding from one that is contracting.

Weakness in construction was a big factor behind the economy's 0.3% decline in the first three months of 2012 and analysts warned that the latest data pointed to another quarter of falling output.

David Tinsley, UK economist at BNP Paribas, said the evidence from the PMI was that construction was contracting at its fastest rate in two-and-a-half years, but that the extra bank holiday to mark the Queen's diamond jubilee probably played a part.

"The weather may also be playing a part – it's close to being the wettest June in England since 1910. Still reports also suggest weaker underlying business conditions, with civil engineering and housing the worst performing areas."

Howard Archer, UK economist at IHS Global Insight said the survey was weak even once the two-day bank holiday at the start of June was taken into account.

"Until recently, construction survey evidence had been appreciably stronger than the hard data which had fuelled hopes that the sector was doing appreciably better than officially reported by the Office for National Statistics. Unfortunately though, it is the survey evidence that is deteriorating rather than the hard data improving."

With the PMI for manufacturing also running below the 50 level, the City is now looking to the Bank of England for fresh stimulus measures at the two-day meeting of Threadneedle Street's monetary policy committee which starts on Wednesday. Analysts believe the Bank's £325bn quantitative easing programme will be expanded by at least £50bn.

webTitle: Bob Diamond's resignation – Q&A

fields.standfirst: Key questions and answers on the background to the Barclays chief's decision to step down, and what happens next
fields.body:
Why has Bob Diamond resigned?

As chief executive of Barclays, he is paying the price for the growing scandal over the bank's attempt to manipulate the interbank lending rates, Libor and Euribor, key benchmark interest rates used around the world to help set the price at which households, individuals and businesses can borrow.

Last week the Financial Services Authority (FSA) and its US counterparts revealed they had fined Barclays £290m for trying to rig Libor and Euribor between 2006 and 2009.

The authorities made it clear that other banks would also be in the firing line and released emails sent between traders and rate setters asking for the rate to be rigged. One of the emails read: "Dude. I owe you big time! Come over one day after work and I'm opening a bottle of Bollinger."

Barclays said 12 traders had been sacked and the problems had been addressed as soon as they were made aware. Diamond and other executives said they would waive their bonuses this year, in the hope that would resolve the matter. But the furore did not die down.

When did Diamond resign?

The Barclays board and Diamond met on Monday night to discuss his position. Marcus Agius (who was, at that time, the former chairman) then called the chancellor, George Osborne, to let him know.

The stock market was informed through the Regulatory News Service at 7.30am on Tuesday in an announcement filed under the fairly dull title "Board changes". It revealed Agius would take over as executive chairman and Diamond would resign with immediate effect.

Hadn't Marcus Agius resigned?

He did on Monday in a failed attempt to save Diamond, who just 24 hours ago told staff he was staying: "I love Barclays, and I am proud of all of you. We all know that these events are not representative of our culture, and it is my responsibility to get to the bottom of that and resolve it."

Agius will take on the chairmanship in an executive role, ie full-time, to search for a new chief executive, partly because regulators could insist that the company should not continue without a chairman and chief executive.

Who is in the running to take over?

The former investment banker Bill Winters, who sat on the independent commission on banking, is the early frontrunner to replace Diamond. He was also co-CEO of the investment bank JP Morgan Chase – one of the few banks to come out of the credit crunch relatively unscathed.

What payoff will Diamond get?

It's too early to say. But investors will be certain to push for it to be the lowest level possible. He has earned £100m in the last six years working for Barclays.

Will he still appear at the Treasury select committee?

Yes. The committee hearings on Wednesday and Thursday are still going ahead, with Diamond appearing on the first day and Agius the next.

Will Diamond leave quietly?

Unlikely. He no longer has the burden of having to cling on to his position when he sits in front of MPs in Portcullis House on Wednesday. He may feel able to open up about the culture at the bank and the relationship between Barclays and the Bank of England. Remember, last time he appeared at the select committee in January 2011 (at a time when he already knew about the rate-rigging investigation) he said it was time for bankers to stop apologising. Don't expect contrition.

How has the City taken it?

Shares in Barclays at 9.50am were up more than 2% on the day. But, remember, they had dropped 15% on the FSA's announcement that the bank would be fined.

What happens next?

Barclays will find a new chief executive, while politicians fight over the scope and structure of a banking inquiry. More banks will be named and shamed over the rate-fixing scandal and more heads will roll. But, as Osborne said, Diamond was running BarCap, the investment side of the bank, when the worst of the corruption was taking place.

webTitle: Arguments against politician-led banking inquiry come large and small

fields.standfirst: It might seem churlish to veto the parliamentary inquiry, but Labour thinks it has good reason to hold out for something better
fields.body:
Labour now faces a dilemma as it considers how to approach the crisis in banking. Andrew Tyrie, the able and independent-minded Conservative MP and Treasury select committee chairman chosen by George Osborne to run the cross-party parliamentary inquiry into banking, has said he will pull out if he does not have all-party support for his work.

So Ed Miliband has the power of veto over this inquiry. Labour can lose Tuesday's vote in the Lords insisting on a full, public, judge-led inquiry and still insist it will not participate.

It might seem churlish, or even defensive, if it blocks an inquiry, but Miliband also feels it has ample reason to hold out for something independent of politicians.

The arguments against a parliamentary inquiry come large and small. Labour said its inquiry would only take 12 months and argued the government inquiry was narrowly drawn, into the handling of Libor, an issue where there was little controversy about reform.

The parliamentary inquiry demanded by Osborne has only 11 sitting weeks to complete its work. Its powers to demand evidence, see correspondence and compel witnesses to tell the truth are questionable. Its composition is vague. It is to be serviced by officials from the Treasury working to a political master. Its chances of reaching a unanimous conclusion in 11 weeks are minimal.

As the culture select committee discovered, partisanship over Rupert Murdoch's suitability to run a company led to a divided and diminished report. Moreover, the atmosphere in parliament around the banking crisis is already badly infected with partisanship. If David Cameron and Osborne had been deadly serious about the importance of a parliamentary inquiry, and the need for speed, they needed to have behaved in a more statesmanlike way on Monday in the Commons.

Osborne, like a schoolteacher, told MPs: "Hands up who was the City minister at the time of the Libor scandal." Within seconds of announcing the inquiry, Cameron pointedly added that it would have powers to compel witnesses to attend, including former City ministers and special advisers, a thinly coded attempt to put Ed Balls and Ed Miliband, the former head of the Treasury's council of economic advisers, in the parliamentary dock.

Tuesday's Daily Mail has a good but politically inspired leak of a document suggesting Lady Vadera, a former Labour Treasury minister close to Gordon Brown, wanted to keep the Libor rate down at the height of the banking crisis.

Who benefits from this leak? The current occupants of the Treasury. The truth may be more subtle, but that is not how Labour views the leak.

Osborne is a brilliant political animal but sometimes he resembles the Pompidou Centre in Paris: all the normally concealed inner architecture is on display to the observer.

His demeanour makes it appear as if he sees a parliamentary inquiry as a one-dimensional attempt to blame Balls for the banking crisis. He would do well to listen to the former chancellor Alistair Darling, who told MPs on Monday a parliamentary inquiry would not work if it were seen as a naked piece of political point-scoring.

Equally, Pat McFadden, the former business minister and no friend of Balls or the old Treasury regime, attacked Osborne for being obsessive in his desire to blame the actions of bankers on the last Labour government. There is also something unhelpful about Osborne repeatedly declaring we know what went wrong.

Fortunately Tyrie does not take kindly to being used as a political pawn. He was furious when he was filmed at the last Tory conference being shepherded into a private room by Steve Hilton, then Cameron's director of strategy, apparently to be lectured on the need to tone down his criticism of government economic policy. He won apologies from those who suggested he was the victim of a punishment beating.

There is a case for a swift inquiry, so that any recommendations can be absorbed into the bills on the future of banking and regulation either before the house or due to be shortly.

It would also be an opportunity for some experienced politicians to hold what Darling described as a truth and reconciliation inquiry into how the bankers became so powerful in British politics. Figures such as Lord Myners, Lord Lawson, Lord Lamont and indeed Lady Vadera would have plenty to say.

But Labour argues that the partisan battle over the nature of the inquiry in the past four days shows how unlikely it is that a politician-led investigation will shed anything much but high heat and low light.

Unless Cameron rethinks, this argument has a few more days to run.

webTitle: Bob Diamond's resignation: reaction from Westminster and the City

fields.standfirst: How politicians, City investors and analysts greeted the surprise departure of the Barclays chief executive
fields.body:
Bob Diamond's resignation came as a surprise to nearly everyone in the City and Westminster. Here's a roundup of reaction so far.

George Osborne, chancellor of the exchequer

"I think it's the right decision for Barclays. I think it's the right decision for the country because we need Barclays focused on lending to our economy, not distracted by this argument of who should be in charge. I hope it's a first step towards a new culture of responsibility in British banking.

"I think Bob Diamond's resignation is a first step towards that change of culture, that new age of responsibility we need to see.

"Barclays was in a particular position where it had the same people who were there when these abuses happened and that's why there was particular pressure."

Ed Miliband, Labour party leader and leader of the opposition

"This was necessary and right. It was clear Bob Diamond was not the man to lead the change that Barclays needed. But this is about more than one man. This is about the culture and practices of the entire banking system, which is why we need an independent, open, judge-led, public inquiry."

Labour MP Tom Watson

Lord Oakeshott – Liberal Democrat peer

"This is a great day. Bob Diamond was the greedy gambler personified. What really matters now is that the criminals inside Barclays … are charged and they are convicted and the full force of the law is brought to bare. Stealing money as a banker is the same thing as stealing from a house."

John Prescott, Labour peer

John Mann, Labour MP, member of Treasury select committee who will question Diamond on Wednesday

"It certainly doesn't draw a line under Barclays. Diamond ought now to be forced to repay the bonuses for the three years when the fraud was going on in the bank and the bank should insist on that. We need the full force of the law used against Barclays.

Shadow business secretary Chuka Umunna

Louise Rouse, director of engagement at FairPensions

"Now that Barclays has confirmed the resignation of Bob Diamond as CEO details must be provided of any severance payments proposed to be made to him.

"Remuneration at Barclays has been a source of controversy for the last few years and shareholders would likely regard it as unacceptable if a CEO departing in such circumstances was to receive severance payments.

"Indeed Mr Diamond's resignation should not mean that Barclays does not seek to claw back his bonuses received during the years when Libor was being manipulated."

Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown stockbrokers

webTitle: Barclays shares rise as Bob Diamond quits

fields.standfirst: Concern over management gap on Barclays board tempers relief
fields.body:
Barclays' shambolic management changes have, for the time being, caused the shares to rally. They opened lower at 163p, but at 9.30am this morning are up 1.3% from yesterday's close at 170.7p.

Investors are clearly mixed over Barclays massive U-turn, which will see chief executive Bob Diamond resign with immediate effect, while chairman Marcus Agius, who announced his intention to resign yesterday, will now stay on.

Overall it seems that worries over a gap in the management at a time of crisis appear to have tempered any relief that Diamond has gone, hopefully clearing the air.

Since the scandal erupted last Wednesday, Barclays has seen more than £4bn slashed from its stock market value, with the shares tumbling 15% last week. On Monday they rallied to a high of 172p and eventually closed the day up 3.4%.

Gary Greenwood of Shore Capital is among those who see it as a positive development. He retains a 'hold' recommendation with a 168p target price, but says investors with a short position should rethink.

In our opinion this is a sensible outcome as Mr Diamond's position at the company had clearly become untenable in the aftermath of the LIBOR fixing scandal. We said yesterday that the decision by Mr Agius to step down would do little to appease the many who felt Mr Diamond should carry the can for the LIBOR fixing scandal, and so it appears to have been the case.
The question now will be who will come in to replace Mr Diamond and whether further senior heads will roll? While the company says that it will consider internal and external candidates to fill the role of CEO, we believe that it is of paramount importance that an external appointment is made in order to clean up the image of the company. We believe the shares should react positively to this news as Mr Diamond's departure removes one of the key drags on sentiment for the company.

Mike Trippitt of Oriel Securities is less upbeat, though he too keeps a 'hold' recommendation on the shares.

Bob Diamond's resignation is surprising. Investor sentiment has deteriorated significantly since Barclays's interbank rate manipulation charges were revealed last week... Bob Diamond's resignation leaves a key management gap and another major uncertainty over the investment case. We reiterate our Hold resignation and 200p target price.

webTitle: George Osborne welcomes Bob Diamond's resignation

fields.standfirst: Chancellor says bank chief's decision to step down over rates scandal is 'right for Barclays and right for the country'
fields.body:
George Osborne has welcomed Bob Diamond's decision to stand down as chief executive of Barclays in the wake of the rate-rigging scandal, saying it was the right decision for the bank and the country.

The chancellor led a cross-party chorus of support for the decision, which the chancellor said he hoped was the first step towards the "new age of responsibility we need to see".

Osborne said he was told of the news by the reinstated Barclays chairman, Marcus Agius, on Monday night. But he insisted that neither he nor fellow ministers had put pressure on Diamond to resign, saying it was up to the Barclays board, not the government, to decide who runs the bank.

He told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme: "I think it's the right decision for Barclays, I think it's the right decision for the country, because we need Barclays bank focused on lending to our economy and not distracted by this argument about who should be in charge. I think and I hope it's the first step towards a new culture of responsibility in British banking."

The move came after Barclays was fined £290m by UK and US regulators for manipulating the Libor and Euribor, the rates at which banks lend to each other.

Diamond, who on Monday issued a memo to staff in which he made clear he had no intention of leaving, finally bowed to pressure to go.

He said in a resignation statement: "The external pressure placed on Barclays has reached a level that risks damaging the franchise … I am deeply disappointed that the impression created by the events announced last week about what Barclays and its people stand for could not be further from the truth."

Diamond said he still intended to appear before the Treasury select committee to give evidence on Wednesday.

Danny Alexander, chief secretary to the Treasury, said there were still many questions for Diamond and the bank to answer.

"It is very important that those questions are answered and that lessons are learned, as well of course as the Serious Fraud Office's consideration of whether prosecutions are possible in this issue," he told BBC Breakfast.

"Of course, I think the bank has decided to do the right thing, the necessary thing, but there are many more questions to answer."

Ed Miliband welcomed Diamond's resignation as "necessary and right" but added that there was a wider issue about the culture of banking and repeated his call for a full inquiry.

"It was clear Bob Diamond was not the man to lead the change that Barclays needed. But this is about more than one man," the Labour leader said in a statement.

"This is about the culture and practices of the entire banking system, which is why we need an independent, open, judge-led, public inquiry."

David Cameron has tried to fend off growing demands for a public inquiry into the loss of trust in British banking by announcing a quick parliamentary inquiry into professional and cultural standards in the industry.

Cameron's proposed inquiry, including peers and MPs, will be chaired by Andrew Tyrie, the respected Conservative chairman of the Treasury select committee. But Tyrie said he may pull out if the inquiry, which will not have an inbuilt Tory majority, does not have cross-party backing.

Witnesses can be compelled to give evidence under oath to the inquiry, which is due to report by the end of December and will be provided with extra research resources by the Treasury.

It will look into what lessons can be learned in relation to "transparency, conflicts of interest, culture and the professional standards of the banking industry".

Osborne dismissed Labour calls for a Leveson-style inquiry into banking practices.

"The people who would be most afraid of where any inquiry goes will be people who were in charge at the time.

"No one more than me would like to see Ed Balls in the dock," quipped Osborne. "But I don't think a long public inquiry that would take months to set up, maybe two years to run, and then lead to legislation in 2016 is frankly what the country wants at the moment. We've had a detailed investigation into what went wrong … what we need to do is put this right. We currently have legislation going before parliament, which we can amend so that we can change the law."

The Lib Dem peer Lord Oakeshott, who led calls for Diamond to resign in the wake of the scandal, said: "Bob Diamond's departure is a great day for democracy. He is the symbol of the gambling and greed we must root out of our banking system. Now the top priority is to catch the criminals, break off the casinos from the basic banks and make them lend.

"We must never again let the rich and powerful in the City or the media get their hands round the windpipe of government."

Mark Field, Conservative MP for Cities of London and Westminster, told Sky News Diamond's resignation was "sensible and pragmatic".

"The real risk was that he would continue to be the story and this was likely to run and run for some considerable time. It's important to state that this is not just affecting Barclays."

fields.standfirst: Chancellor George Osborne says Diamond's exit after interest rate scandal was 'right decision for Barclays and for country'
fields.body:
Bob Diamond has resigned from Barclays in the face of relentless political pressure for him to go following the interest rate manipulation scandal.

An attempt by the board to save his position by accepting the resignation of the chairman, Marcus Agius, on Monday has failed. Instead Agius will now become full-time chairman and lead the search for a new chief executive.

In a stunning turnaround – only on Monday the 60-year old chief executive was vowing to stay – Diamond is to go immediately after a 15-year career with the bank and only 18 months as chief executive.

Diamond's resignation was welcomed by the government, which has come under increasing pressure to launch a public inquiry into the scandal. George Osborne, speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, said it was "the right decision for Barclays – and for the country".

"I think Bob Diamond's resignation is the first step towards the new age of responsibility we need to see."

Asked whether he had played a part in Diamond's exit, the chancellor denied it, saying he was not in his job to decide who ran Britain's banks.

Osborne also condemned the City's "corrupt practices", suggesting that criminal cases over the bank's manipulation of the inter-bank lending rate would follow, even though no one responsible has yet been charged with any offence.

Ed Miliband said Diamond's departure was "necessary and right", but repeated his call for a public inquiry.

"This is about more than one man," the Labour leader said. "This is about the culture and practices of the entire banking system which is why we need an independent, open, judge-led, public inquiry."

But Diamond's decision to quit – and the return of Agius – dismayed some in the City.

One investor said: "We are clearly now left with the worst of all possible situations. We don't have a ready-made candidate and a chairman who has no credibility."

After an initial fall this morning, Barclays shares edged 1% higher to 170.5p, reflecting a view that the the worst of the political storm may have been passed. They fell 15% last week, wiping £4bn from Barclays' stock market value.

Diamond, 60, is understood to have decided to go on Monday evening, and informed the board of his decision. But one source said it was a matter of semantics as to whether Diamond went or was pushed.

There is no mention in Barclays' statement of any compensation for Diamond, but shareholders are determined that it should be kept to a minimum. Since Diamond's pay was first disclosed by Barclays in 2006 he has amassed £100m in pay and perks.

The former investment banker Bill Winters, who sat on the independent commission on banking, will be regarded as a candidate to succeed Diamond, whose attempts to focus on the bank's commitment to "citizenship" have speculatorly backfired.

Diamond said: "My motivation has always been to do what I believed to be in the best interests of Barclays. No decision over that period was as hard as the one that I make now to stand down as chief executive. The external pressure placed on Barclays has reached a level that risks damaging the franchise – I cannot let that happen.

"I am deeply disappointed that the impression created by the events announced last week about what Barclays and its people stand for could not be further from the truth. I know that each and every one of the people at Barclays works hard every day to serve our customers and clients."

Diamond will still appear before MPs on the Treasury select committee on Wednesday where he is expected to face tough questioning about when he knew about the bank's manipulation of the London inter-bank offered rate (Libor).

Last week Barclays was ordered to pay £290m to settle claims that it used underhand tactics to try to rig financial markets. The penalties from UK and US regulators, including a record £59.5m fine from the Financial Services Authority, follow allegations it manipulated Libor and Euribor interbank lending, which govern the rates at which banks are prepared to lend to each other in the wholesale money markets.

Agius said: "As chief executive he [Diamond] has led the bank superbly. I look forward to working closely with the chief executives of our businesses and the other members of the executive committee in leading Barclays' world class businesses in serving our customers and clients and delivering value for our shareholders."

The Lib Dem peer Lord Oakeshott said: "This is a great day. Bob Diamond was the greedy gambler, personified. What really matters now is that the criminals inside Barclays, that they are charged and they are convicted and the full force of the law is brought to bear. Stealing money as a banker is the same thing as stealing from a house."

Marcus will chair the Barclays executive committee pending the appointment of a new chief executive and he will be supported in discharging these responsibilities by Sir Michael Rake, deputy chairman.

The search for a new chief executive will commence immediately and will consider both internal and external candidates. The businesses will continue to be managed by the existing leadership teams.

Bob Diamond said: "I joined Barclays 16 years ago because I saw an opportunity to build a world class investment banking business. Since then, I have had the privilege of working with some of the most talented, client-focused and diligent people that I have ever come across. We built world class businesses together and added our own distinctive chapter to the long and proud history of Barclays. My motivation has always been to do what I believed to be in the best interests of Barclays. No decision over that period was as hard as the one that I make now to stand down as chief executive. The external pressure placed on Barclays has reached a level that risks damaging the franchise – I cannot let that happen.

"I am deeply disappointed that the impression created by the events announced last week about what Barclays and its people stand for could not be further from the truth. I know that each and every one of the people at Barclays works hard every day to serve our customers and clients. That is how we support economic growth and the communities in which we live and work. I look forward to fulfilling my obligation to contribute to the Treasury committee's enquiries related to the settlements that Barclays announced last week without my leadership in question.

"I leave behind an extraordinarily talented management team that I know is well placed to help the business emerge from this difficult period as one of the leaders in the global banking industry."

Commenting, Marcus Agius said: "Bob Diamond has made an enormous contribution to Barclays over the last 16 years of distinguished service to the group, building Barclays Investment Bank into one of the leading global investment banks in the world. As chief executive he has led the bank superbly. I look forward to working closely with the chief executives of our businesses and the other members of the executive committee in leading Barclays world class businesses in serving our customers and clients and delivering value for our shareholders."

webTitle: David Cameron orders speedy bank inquiry

fields.bodyText: David Cameron has tried to fend off growing demands for a public inquiry into the loss of trust in British banking by announcing a quick parliamentary inquiry into professional and cultural standards in the industry. Desperate to avoid being wrong-footed, as he was last summer over Labour calls for a public inquiry into phone hacking, Cameron and the chancellor, George Osborne, tried to seize the political initiative by claiming the cross-party inquiry could examine how the previous government had left the City so unregulated. Cameron's proposed inquiry, including peers and MPs, will be chaired by Andrew Tyrie, the respected Conservative chairman of the Treasury select committee. It will not have an inbuilt Tory majority. Witnesses can be compelled to give evidence under oath. It is due to report by the end of December and will be provided with extra research resources by the Treasury. It will look into what lessons can be learned in relation to "transparency, conflicts of interest, culture and the professional standards of the banking industry". Previously ministers had rejected Labour's call for a retrospective inquiry, but on Monday morning Downing Street changed tack, sensing potential revenge for the agony caused by the Leveson inquiry by turning attention to Labour's role in allowing the Libor interest rate scandal now engulfing Barclays bank. But the government also argued that a speedy inquiry could draw up recommendations in time for inclusion in a banking bill next spring, implementing the Vickers Commission report on dividing retail and so-called casino banking. Osborne told MPs: "We need to get on with this – not spend years on costly navel-gazing when we know what has gone wrong." The announcement came as the resignation of the Barclays chairman, Marcus Agius, failed to puncture the pressure enveloping the bank since it was slapped with a record £290m fine for attempting to manipulate interest rates. With politicians continuing to call for the chief executive to step aside, Bob Diamond issued a memo to staff in which he made clear he had no intention of leaving. "I am disappointed because many of these behaviours happened on my watch. It is my responsibility to make sure that it cannot happen again," Diamond said. He will appear before Tyrie's Treasury select committee on Wednesday . Agius, who earned £751,000 a year, is on six months' notice and will stay while a successor is found after saying he was "truly sorry" for the interest rate rigging scandal that has dealt a "devastating blow" to the bank's reputation. "As chairman, I am the ultimate guardian of the bank's reputation. Accordingly, the buck stops with me and I must acknowledge responsibility by standing aside," Agius said. But some shareholders disagree and believe the new chairman – whose appointment could take as along as six months and requires approval from the Financial Services Authority – should be responsible for finding a successor to Diamond. Barclays' shares, which had lost £4bn in value in 72 hours after the fine was announced last Friday, edged higher to close 3% up, but with still much ground to regain after the 15% fall. As well as the parliamentary inquiry and the select committee session, Barclays will also have to weather further scrutiny of its alleged role in manipulating Libor (the London interbank offered rate). In the Commons yesterday, the housing minister Grant Shapps acknowledged that the Libor scandal could have contributed to home repossessions. Osborne appointed Martin Wheatley, the Financial Conduct Authority chairman-designate, to run a separate narrow inquiry into the future setting of Libor, the rate at which banks lend between themselves. Osborne urged the Serious Fraud Office to use every avenue to prosecute Barclays traders who may have broken the law. Labour vowed to press for a full public inquiry and dismissed Cameron's remedy as a case of the "establishment closing ranks around its own". Labour did not say if it would boycott the parliamentary inquiry if it could not persuade Cameron to change his plans. Labour fears that an inquiry led by a politician – rather than a judge – will descend into partisan point-scoring grew when Cameron immediately pointed out that it could take evidence from former City ministers and special advisers, a reference to Ed Balls and Ed Miliband. Osborne said Balls was the City minister at the time of the Libor scandal, and predicted the inquiry would find out in due course what Balls and the former prime minister Gordon Brown knew about that scandal. Labour accused Osborne of being obsessed with blaming the last Labour government for every action of every banker. Balls tried to widen responsibility for the bankers' actions over the last decade: "The public are angry and they rightly ask whether this generation of politicians, regulators and banks can put right these wrongs." He added: "We should all admit that regulation should have been tougher and we should all learn the lessons of an open judicial led inquiry." The ex-chancellor Alistair Darling said: "This inquiry will only work if it is a genuine examination of what went wrong. But if looks like a partisan exercise in settling scores between the political parties, it will not work. The public may not like bankers, but they do not like politicians either." Barclays was fined for attempting to fix Libor and the European equivalent, Euribor – two benchmarks that are the basis for pricing an array of financial products, potentially affecting the price at which households and businesses borrow money.
